fr:mainmatter.fr:p: PhD student at Royal Holloway, University of London researching programming language semantics via cyclic proof theory, type theory, and category theory. Supervised by Reuben Rowe.
Senior Lecturer in Computer Science.

Let S 	riangleright P and T 	riangleright Q be containers. We define their composite S 	riangleright P \circ T 	riangleright Q as the container \sum _{s : S} P\ s 	o T 	riangleright \lambda (s , f) . \sum _{p : P\ s} Q\ (f\ p) This composition commutes with container extension, which is to say: \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack S 	riangleright P \circ T 	riangleright Q brack 
egthinspace brack \cong \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack S 	riangleright P brack 
egthinspace brack \circ \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack T 	riangleright Q brack 
egthinspace brack

fr:title.text: Methods of obtaining distributive law results

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Methods of obtaining distributive law results

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
I've been reviewing the literature on distributive laws, specifically those papers that Dan Marsden mentioned, and have found some candidates for methods that we could attempt to adapt to finding monad container distributive laws:
Generalising the "abides" property in [zwartmarsden2022] to monad containers - looks like it would be some funky equation on positions in \sigma shapes.
Manes and Mulry I Theorem 4.3.4 mentions something about distributive laws between commutative monads - this might be adaptable.
"Multiple constants" in [zwartmarsden2022] would correspond to multiple shapes having singleton position sets.
Manes and Mulry use "Kleisli strengths" to show distributive laws, we should see what those are in the case of monad containers.

fr:title.text: Monad container composition via distributive law

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monad container composition via distributive law

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (S \triangleright P, \iota ^S, \sigma ^S, \text {pr}^S) and (T \triangleright Q, \iota ^T, \sigma ^T, \text {pr}^T) be monad containers and (u_1 , u_2 , v_1 , v_2) be a monad container distributive law of type T \triangleright Q \circ S \triangleright P \Rightarrow S \triangleright P \circ T \triangleright Q.

Given a container (S 	riangleright P), it's extension is defined as the \mathbf {Set}-functor \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack S 	riangleright P brack 
egthinspace brack with action on objects \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack S 	riangleright P brack 
egthinspace brack \ A := \sum _{s : S} P\ s 	o A and action on morphisms (\lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack S 	riangleright P brack 
egthinspace brack \ f)\ (s , g) := (s , f \circ g)

The operation \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack - brack 
egthinspace brack can be extended to a functor from \mathbf {Cont} to [\mathbf {Set},\mathbf {Set}] by mapping container morphisms to natural transformations as follows \langle 
egthinspace \langle u 	riangleright v angle 
egthinspace angle _A\ (s , f) := (u\ s , f \circ v) The functor given by \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack - brack 
egthinspace brack and \langle 
egthinspace \langle - angle 
egthinspace angle is fully faithful.

fr:title.text: Diary: Relation between container distributive laws and matching pairs of monoids/Zappa-Szép products

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Diary: Relation between container distributive laws and matching pairs of monoids/Zappa-Szép products

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Previous entry, Next entry

fr:title.text: Relation between container distributive laws and matching pairs of monoids/Zappa-Szép products

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Relation between container distributive laws and matching pairs of monoids/Zappa-Szép products

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: As mentioned in [ahmanuustalu2013], directed container distributive laws are generalisations of matching pairs of monoid actions. Further, composition of directed containers via a distributive law is a generalisation of the Zappa-Szép product of two monoids. As mentioned in the paper, you can actually recover the definition of a matching pair by looking at distributive laws between representable directed containers.

fr:title.text: Directed container distributive law between representables

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Directed container distributive law between representables

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: As it turns out, monad container distributive laws are also a generalisation of matching pairs of monoid actions. This is a bit harder to see than in the directed container case, but as before we can recover the data and equations for a matching pair by specialising the distributive law to a particular type of monad container.

fr:title.text: Monad container distributive law between writers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monad container distributive law between writers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: As shown, both of these types of distributive law are generalisations of matching pairs of monoid actions, each in a slightly different way. For directed containers the generalisation is "in the direction of the shapes", and for monad containers the generalisation is "in the direction of the positions".

fr:title.text: Directed container distributive law between representables

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Directed container distributive law between representables

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Today we discussed the reading that we did over the last week. We singled out the fully extended Boom heirarchy (Table 4 in Zwart and Marsdens paper "Don't try this at home") as a good source of potential monad combinations to check for distributive laws between. Stef mentioned that Andras Kovacs' PhD thesis talks about the link between "Generalized algebraic theories" and QIITs.

To make use of the Boom heirarchy, we are going to put together an Overleaf document describing the algebraic theories for each monad in it, and then check for each whether they can be represented as a monad container.

Actionables:
Look into developing no-go theorems by restricting view to constant functions - developing distributive laws for lmf-containers might help in this direction. If we adopt this restriction, we can also consider commutative monad containers.
At least skim p.83 of Andras' thesis.
Start writing up ideas on algebraic theories/monad containers corresponding to monads in the Boom heirarchy.

fr:title.text: Monad container distributive law between writers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monad container distributive law between writers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This can be extended to a fully faithful functor from the category of monad containers and monad container maps to the category of \mathbf {Set}-monads and monad maps. [uustalu2017]

fr:title.text: Relation between container distributive laws and matching pairs of monoids/Zappa-Szép products

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Relation between container distributive laws and matching pairs of monoids/Zappa-Szép products

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: As mentioned in [ahmanuustalu2013], directed container distributive laws are generalisations of matching pairs of monoid actions. Further, composition of directed containers via a distributive law is a generalisation of the Zappa-Szép product of two monoids. As mentioned in the paper, you can actually recover the definition of a matching pair by looking at distributive laws between representable directed containers.

fr:title.text: Directed container distributive law between representables

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Directed container distributive law between representables

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: As it turns out, monad container distributive laws are also a generalisation of matching pairs of monoid actions. This is a bit harder to see than in the directed container case, but as before we can recover the data and equations for a matching pair by specialising the distributive law to a particular type of monad container.

fr:title.text: Monad container distributive law between writers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monad container distributive law between writers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: As shown, both of these types of distributive law are generalisations of matching pairs of monoid actions, each in a slightly different way. For directed containers the generalisation is "in the direction of the shapes", and for monad containers the generalisation is "in the direction of the positions".

fr:title.text: Coproduct monad container distribution on the left

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Coproduct monad container distribution on the left

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
The coproduct monad container 1 + E \triangleright T distributes over any monad container S \triangleright P in exactly one way.
380#246unstable-246.xmlProof20241210Chris Purdy We have given the first 4 equations for a monad container distributive law and the isomorphisms T\ (\text {inl}\ *) \to S \cong S and T\ (\text {inr}\ e) \to S \cong 1 that: \begin {align*} &u\ (\text {inl}\ *)\ (\lambda \_ . s) = (s , \lambda \_ . \text {inl}\ *)\\ &u\ (\text {inr}\ e)\ f = u\ (\text {inr}\ e)\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ^S) = (\iota ^S , \lambda \_ . \text {inr}\ e)\\ &v\ \{\text {inl}\ *\}\ \{\lambda \_ . s\}\ (p , *) = (* , p) \end {align*} These constraints entirely define u, and therefore v also. Since the other distributive law equalities hold, u and v specify the unique distributive law (1 + E \triangleright T) \circ (S \triangleright P) \Rightarrow (S \triangleright P) \circ (1 + E \triangleright T).

fr:title.text: Algebraic theories for cartesian monad containers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebraic theories for cartesian monad containers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
The Set-functor interpretation of a finitary cartesian monad container (S 	riangleright P, \iota , \sigma ) is the same as that of the algebraic theory consisting of an operation \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack s brack 
egthinspace brack with arity n \cong P\ s for each s : S, and the following equations:
 egin {align*} \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack \sigma \ \iota \ (\lambda \_ . s) brack 
egthinspace brack \ \vec {t} &= \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack s brack 
egthinspace brack \ \vec {t}\ \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack \sigma \ s\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ) brack 
egthinspace brack \ \vec {t} &= \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack s brack 
egthinspace brack \ \vec {t}\ \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack \sigma \ (\sigma \ s\ f)\ g brack 
egthinspace brack \ \vec {t} &= \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack \sigma \ s\ (\lambda i . \sigma \ (f\ i)\ (g\ i)) brack 
egthinspace brack \ \vec {t} \end {align*}
Previous entry, Next entry

This morning and yesterday evening I was trying to work out what monad containers correspond to algebraic theories. Since algebraic theories interpret finitary monads, I first worked out when monad containers are finitary; lemma 1.7.3 from Joachim Kock's "Notes on Polynomial Functors" shows that this is exactly when the position sets are finite.

By considering the algebras for a monad conatiner, it became pretty clear that the algebraic theory corresponding to a monad container essentially has an operation for each shape which interact in accordance with the monad container equalities.
  295lsd-0019lsd-0019.xmlMonad container algebrasDefinition2024129Chris Purdy
An algebra for a monad container (S 	riangleright  P, \iota , \sigma , 	ext {pr}) is a pair (A, \alpha ) of a set A and a map \alpha  : \prod _{s : S} (P\ s 	o  A) 	o  A, satisfying:
        egin {align*}       \alpha \ \iota \ (\lambda  \_ . a) &= a\       \alpha \ (\sigma \ s\ f)\ (g \circ  	ext {pr}) &= \alpha \ s\ (\lambda  p . \alpha \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p))      \end {align*}   
  297lsd-0020lsd-0020.xmlAlgebraic theories for cartesian monad containersProposition2024129Chris Purdy
The Set-functor interpretation of a finitary cartesian monad container (S 	riangleright  P, \iota , \sigma ) is the same as that of the algebraic theory consisting of an operation \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  s brack 
egthinspace brack  with arity n \cong  P\ s for each s : S, and the following equations:
  
        egin {align*}            \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  \sigma \ \iota \ (\lambda  \_ . s) brack 
egthinspace brack \ \vec {t} &= \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  s brack 
egthinspace brack \ \vec {t}\     \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  \sigma \ s\ (\lambda  \_ . \iota ) brack 
egthinspace brack \ \vec {t} &= \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  s brack 
egthinspace brack \ \vec {t}\     \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  \sigma \ (\sigma \ s\ f)\ g brack 
egthinspace brack \ \vec {t} &= \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  \sigma \ s\ (\lambda  i . \sigma \ (f\ i)\ (g\ i)) brack 
egthinspace brack \ \vec {t}        \end {align*}   
  I'm only considering cartesian monad containers for now, since their algebraic theories were much easier to describe - I'm not exactly sure how to phrase the equations in the non-cartesian case. For example, \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  \iota  brack 
egthinspace brack  is not necessarily unary in that case, and \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  \sigma \ s\ f brack 
egthinspace brack  may have fewer arguments than the sum of the arities of each \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  f(i) brack 
egthinspace brack  - the resulting equations feel rather unnatural.
I think [gambinokock2013] describes all of this in a more general form. A good reference describing filtered colimits is the Stacks project.

An aside: I also found this presentation by Steve Awodey that describes the link between polynomial functors/monads and models of type theory, which probably links closely to the concept of \Sigma -universes.

EDIT (12/12/24): I realised that I was missing the associativity equation for the definition of the algebraic theory for a finitary cartesian monad container, and in the process realised that finitary cartesian monad containers are exactly non-symmetric operads!

To show this, consider (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma ). The set (or type) of operations for each n : \mathbb {N} is given by n \mapsto \sum _{s : S} |\negthinspace | P\ s \cong n |\negthinspace | where \iota is the identity operation, and \sigma is composition. All operations have finite arity by the finitary assumption on the monad container.

That monad containers were generalisations of non-symmetric operads (in this way) was already noticed by Tarmo Uustalu in [uustalu2017], but an explicit construction showing how they can be recovered was not given. Based on the rest of this post, I believe that Tarmo's generalisation of the list monad container in terms of any non-symmetric operad characterises exactly the cartesian monad containers that correspond to algebraic theories.

A container S \triangleright P is finitary when its extension functor is finitary (preserves filtered colimits). A monad container is finitary when the underlying container is. 392#245unstable-245.xmlProposition2024129Chris Purdy
A container is finitary if and only if for all s : S, the set P\ s is isomorphic to some finite cardinal. TODO: reference Kock here

An algebra for a monad container (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) is a pair (A, \alpha ) of a set A and a map \alpha : \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to A) \to A, satisfying: \begin {align*} \alpha \ \iota \ (\lambda \_ . a) &= a\\ \alpha \ (\sigma \ s\ f)\ (g \circ \text {pr}) &= \alpha \ s\ (\lambda p . \alpha \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p)) \end {align*}

A repository of notes I've made for meetings with my supervisor, collaborators and others.
444mee-0002mee-0002.xmlMeeting notes: Stef 11/12/2420241211Chris PurdyStefania Damato
Today we discussed the reading that we did over the last week. We singled out the fully extended Boom heirarchy (Table 4 in Zwart and Marsdens paper "Don't try this at home") as a good source of potential monad combinations to check for distributive laws between. Stef mentioned that Andras Kovacs' PhD thesis talks about the link between "Generalized algebraic theories" and QIITs.
To make use of the Boom heirarchy, we are going to put together an Overleaf document describing the algebraic theories for each monad in it, and then check for each whether they can be represented as a monad container.
Actionables:
Look into developing no-go theorems by restricting view to constant functions - developing distributive laws for lmf-containers might help in this direction. If we adopt this restriction, we can also consider commutative monad containers.
At least skim p.83 of Andras' thesis.
Start writing up ideas on algebraic theories/monad containers corresponding to monads in the Boom heirarchy.447mee-0001mee-0001.xmlMeeting notes: Stef 05/12/242024125Chris PurdyStefania Damato
We need to read the current literature on distributive laws in order to tie our work in and work out what results of ours are significant. For next week we should read
No Go Theorems: Directed Containers That Do Not Distribute Over Distribution Monads
Maaike Zwart's thesis
Kleisli and Eilenberg-Moore laws/liftings: Dan's blog post

We need to read the current literature on distributive laws in order to tie our work in and work out what results of ours are significant. For next week we should read
No Go Theorems: Directed Containers That Do Not Distribute Over Distribution Monads
Maaike Zwart's thesis
Kleisli and Eilenberg-Moore laws/liftings: Dan's blog post

fr:title.text: Representable monad container distribution on the right

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Representable monad container distribution on the right

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Any monad container S \triangleright P distributes over a representable monad container 1 \triangleright \lambda \_ . A in exactly one way.
440#247unstable-247.xmlProof2024125Chris Purdy By considering the data for a monad container distributive law, we get by the first four equalities, and for all s : S the isomorphism P\ s \to 1 \cong 1, that: \begin {align*} u\ s\ \_ &:= (* , \lambda \_ . s)\\ v\ p\ a &:= (a , p) \end {align*} u and v are entirely specified by the "unit" equalities, and the rest of the equalities hold. Hence this is the unique monad distributive law of S \triangleright P over 1 \triangleright \lambda \_ . A.

The Coproduct monad container for a set E is given by the data 1 + E \triangleright T where T\ (\text {inl}\ *) := 1, T\ (\text {inr}\ \_) := 0 and: \begin {align*} \iota &:= \text {inl}\ *\\ \sigma \ (\text {inl}\ *)\ f &:= f\ *\\ \sigma \ (\text {inr}\ e)\ f &:= \text {inr}\ e\\ \text {pr}\ * &:= (* , *) \end {align*} This is the unique monad container structure that you can give the container 1 + E \triangleright T [uustalu2017]. This also happens to be a cartesian monad container. \text {pr} is well-defined up to function extensionality by induction on its implicit arguments.

The List monad container is given by the data \mathbb {N} \triangleright \text {Fin} and: \begin {align*} \iota &:= 1\\ \sigma \ n\ f &:= \sum _{i = 0}^n f\ i\\ \text {pr}_1\ \{n\}\ \{f\}\ m &:= \text {greatest } i \in \lbrack 0 .. n \rparen \text { where } \sum _{j = 0}^i f\ j \leq m \\ \text {pr}_2\ \{n\}\ \{f\}\ m &:= m - (\sum _{j = 0}^{\text {pr}_1\ \{n\}\ \{f\}\ m} f\ j) \end {align*}

The Maybe monad can be represented as the monad container 2 \triangleright T where T\ \text {true} := 1, T\ \text {false} := 0 and: \begin {align*} \iota &:= \text {true}\\ \sigma \ \text {true}\ f &:= f\ *\\ \sigma \ \text {false}\ f &:= \text {false}\\ \text {pr}\ * &:= (* , *) \end {align*} This is a special case of the Coproduct monad container.
It might be possible to change the type of the shapes to some M-type to allow for this monad container to be definable in MLTT for example.

A random unorganised thought: since there seems to be some connection between the State monad container and the S(K?)I combinator calculus, maybe \sigma here can act as different interpretation of the S combinator?
Simple type environments, denoted \mathcal {H}, are finite partial maps from expression variables to tuples of a variance annotation and a domain.

When \mathcal {H}(x) is undefined for all x we say \mathcal {H} is empty. Abusing notation, we write x^v : T \in \mathcal {H} to mean \mathcal {H}(x) = (v , T), and \mathcal {H} \subseteq \mathcal {H}^\prime to mean that x^v : T \in \mathcal {H} implies x^v : T \in \mathcal {H}^\prime .
Simple type environments, denoted \mathcal {H}, are finite partial maps from expression variables to tuples of a variance annotation and a domain.

When \mathcal {H}(x) is undefined for all x we say \mathcal {H} is empty. Abusing notation, we write x^v : T \in \mathcal {H} to mean \mathcal {H}(x) = (v , T), and \mathcal {H} \subseteq \mathcal {H}^\prime to mean that x^v : T \in \mathcal {H} implies x^v : T \in \mathcal {H}^\prime .
For all simple type environments we have (\mathcal {H}^-)^- = \mathcal {H}.

fr:title.text: Simple type environment negation preserves inclusion

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Simple type environment negation preserves inclusion

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For all simple type environments we have \mathcal {H}_1 \subseteq \mathcal {H}_2 if and only if \mathcal {H}_1^- \subseteq \mathcal {H}_2^-.
For all simple type environments we have (\mathcal {H}^-)^- = \mathcal {H}.

fr:title.text: Simple type environment negation preserves inclusion

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Simple type environment negation preserves inclusion

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For all simple type environments we have \mathcal {H}_1 \subseteq \mathcal {H}_2 if and only if \mathcal {H}_1^- \subseteq \mathcal {H}_2^-.
Interestingly it seems to consist of the combinators S (a version with flipped arguments) and I. Is there some deeper connection to combinatory logic here?

The Writer monad container for a monoid (A, \otimes , e) is given by the data A \triangleright \lambda \_ . 1 and: \begin {align*} \iota &:= e\\ \sigma \ a\ b\ &:= a \otimes (b\ *)\\ \text {pr}\ * &:= (*, *) \end {align*}

The syntax of \mu HOL^{ex} formulae has a small logical fragment, extended with a fixed-point operator, variance annotations [viswanathanviswanathan2004] and contraints for ordinal variables. v ranges over variance annotations, and P, T range over predicate and non-predicate domains respectively. t ::=\ x\ |\ \forall (x : T).t\ |\ t \Rightarrow t^\prime \ |\ \lambda (x^v : T).t\ |\ t\ t^\prime \ |\ \mu ^\alpha (x:P).t\ |\ \exists \alpha .t\ |\ \beta < \alpha

Let (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a monad containers. It is cartesian iff P\ \iota \cong 1 and \text {pr} is an isomorphism. This is equivalent to saying that the extension of the monad container is a cartesian monad (container functors always preserve pullbacks).
These can also be seen as proper (1,\Sigma ) type universes (Tarski-style).

Let (S \triangleright P, \iota ^S, \sigma ^S, \text {pr}^S) and (T \triangleright Q, \iota ^T, \sigma ^T, \text {pr}^T) be monad containers. A distributive law of S \triangleright P over T \triangleright Q is given by the data: \begin {align*} &u_1 : \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to T) \to T \\ &u_2 : \prod _{s : S} \prod _{f : P\ s \to T} Q\ (u_1\ s\ f) \to S \\ &v_1 : \prod _{\{s : S\}} \prod _{\{f : P\ s \to T\}} \prod _{q : Q\ (u_1\ s\ f)} P\ (u_2\ s\ f\ q) \to P\ s \\ &v_2 : \prod _{\{s : S\}} \prod _{\{f : P\ s \to T\}} \prod _{q : Q\ (u_1\ s\ f)} \prod _{p : P\ (u_2\ s\ f\ q)} Q\ (f\ (v_1\ q\ p)) \\ \end {align*} where the following equalities hold: \begin {align*} u\ \iota ^S\ (\lambda \_ . t) &= (t , \lambda \_ . \iota ^S)\\ u\ s\ (\lambda \_. \iota ^T) &= (\iota ^T , \lambda \_. s)\\ v\ \{\iota ^S\}\ \{\lambda \_. t\} &= \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle \\ v\ \{s\}\ \{\lambda \_. \iota ^T\} &= \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle \\ \\ u_1\ (\sigma ^S\ s\ f)\ (g \circ \text {pr}^S) &= u_1\ s\ (u_1 \circ \langle f , g \rangle )\\ u_2\ (\sigma ^S\ s\ f)\ (g \circ \text {pr}^S)\ q &= \sigma ^S\ (u_2\ s\ (u_1 \circ \langle f , g \rangle )\ q)\ (\lambda p . u_2\ (f\ (v_1\ q\ p))\ (g\ (v_1\ q\ p))\ (v_2\ q\ p))\\ \text {pr}^S_1\ (v_1\ q\ p) &= v_1\ q\ (\text {pr}^S_1\ p)\\ \text {pr}^S_2\ (v_1\ q\ p) &= v_1\ (v_2\ q\ (\text {pr}^S_1\ p))\ (\text {pr}^S_2\ p)\\ v_2\ q\ p &= v_2\ (v_2\ q\ (\text {pr}^S_1\ p))\ (\text {pr}^S_2\ p)\\ \\ u_1\ s\ (\sigma ^T \circ \langle f , g \rangle ) &= \sigma ^T\ (u_1\ s\ f)\ (\lambda q . u_1\ (u_2\ s\ f\ q)\ (\lambda p . g\ (v_1\ q\ p)\ (v_2\ q\ p)))\\ u_2\ s\ (\sigma ^T \circ \langle f , g \rangle )\ q &= u_2\ (u_2\ s\ f\ (\text {pr}^T_1\ q))\ (\lambda p . g\ (v_1\ q\ p)\ (v_2\ q\ p))\ (\text {pr}^T_2\ q)\\ v_1\ (\text {pr}^T_1\ q)\ (v_1\ (\text {pr}^T_2\ q)\ p) &= v_1\ q\ p\\ v_2\ (\text {pr}^T_1\ q)\ (v_1\ (\text {pr}^T_2\ q)\ p) &= \text {pr}^T_1\ (v_2\ q\ p)\\ v_2\ (\text {pr}^T_2\ q)\ p &= \text {pr}^T_2\ (v_2\ q\ p) \end {align*} We use the notation \langle f , g \rangle := \lambda x . (f\ x , g\ x), with some implicit use of currying and uncurrying where this shorthand is utilised.
u is defined as \langle u_1 , u_2 \rangle and v is defined as \langle v_1 , v_2 \rangle .
Monad container distributive laws allow you to define a notion of composition for monad containers.
Here's a compilation of monad container and monad container distributive law examples for reference.

Properties/classes of monad containers:
Cartesian
Finitary
Idempotent
Commutative
Affine

"Specific" monad containers:
Representable
Maybe
Writer
Coproduct
List
State
Reverse State - just a curiosity, only definable in a theory with unrestricted fixed points
TODO: Update
TODO: Free

Distributive laws:
Any monad container over a representable one
Coproduct over any monad container
Writer over writer

fr:title.text: Variance typing system for HOL^{ex} formulae

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Variance typing system for \mu HOL^{ex} formulae

fr:title.text: Idempotent monad containers are almost trivial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Idempotent monad containers are almost trivial

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A monad T is idempotent when T \eta = \eta T, which for monad containers immediately gives us \iota = s for all s : S, and hence S is contractible.

Another equivalent condition for a monad T to be idempotent is that \text {Id} is a distributive law TT \Rightarrow TT. For monad container distributive laws this implies futher that all positions are equal, so the set P\ \iota is subsingleton.

The extension of a monad container (S 	riangleright  P, \iota , \sigma , 	ext {pr}) is the Set monad on \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  S 	riangleright  P brack 
egthinspace brack  given by the data:
        egin {align*}       \eta _A &: A 	o  \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  S 	riangleright  P brack 
egthinspace brack \ A\       \eta _A\ a &:= (\iota  , \lambda  \_ . a)\       \       \mu _A &: \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  S 	riangleright  P brack 
egthinspace brack \ S 	riangleright  \lambda  (s , f) . \sum _{p : P\ s} P (f\ p) brack 
egthinspace brack \ A 	o  \lbrack 
egthinspace \lbrack  S 	riangleright  P brack 
egthinspace brack \ A\       \mu _A\ ((s , f) , g) &:= (\sigma \ s\ f , g \circ  	ext {pr})     \end {align*}   
  The monad laws hold by the monad container laws on \iota , \sigma  and 	ext {pr}.

fr:title.text: There is only one representable monad container

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: There is only one representable monad container

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given the container 1 \triangleright \lambda \_ . A, we look at the required data for a monad container. \iota and \sigma \ a\ b are trival (both are elements of 1). The equations for \text {pr} force it to be defined as the diagonal map: \text {pr}\ a := (a , a)

fr:title.text: All affine monad containers are representable

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: All affine monad containers are representable

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a commutative monad container. By taking the categorical definition of affine monads and specialising it to monad container extensions, we get for all a, b : S the equation: \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . b) = a Since we have a point \iota : S, we can conclude that S is contractible. Hence we have that S \triangleright P is 1 \triangleright \lambda \_ . P\ \iota .

Let (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a monad container. We call the monad container commutative when the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . b) &= \sigma \ b\ (\lambda \_ . a)\\ \text {pr}_1\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ p\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_1\ p \end {align*} The equations for \text {pr} holds given the first equation. Commutative monad containers interpret exactly the commutative monads (w.r.t. cartesian product) for container functors. [uustalu2017]
Previous entry, Next entry

Earlier this week Stef and I were working on the monad container distributive law project. We had a very insightful meeting with Dan Marsden who mentioned (among other things) that we should look for applications for our characterisation. Things to try:
Find characterisations for tighter classes of monad containers (i.e. commutative, affine, relevant) and see if this simplifies the distributive law. We have already characterised distributive laws for cartesian monad containers for example.
Prove more than just mere existence of distributive laws - use the characterisation to find exactly how many there are for a given pair of monad containers.
Over-approximate distributive law requirements to have an easier time with the above. For example, we could consider when the position map v is just \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , which often seems to be the case in simpler examples.
Find which algebraic theories correspond to container monads, to tie our work to Maaike Zwart and Dan's work on distributive laws for algebraic theories.
\mu HOL^{ex} is a logic and cyclic proof system that I've been developing for part of my PhD project with my supervisor Reuben Rowe.

The goal is to develop a proof system for higher-order logic with fixed-point operators, that allows for induction and coinduction by adding fixed-point "unfolding" rules, and allowing proofs to be cyclic.

Joint work with Stefania Damato on characterising distributive laws between monad containers. Monad containers were originally characterised by Tarmo Uustalu - these are containers with extra structure such that their interpretation as \mathbf {Set} functors are monads.

This characterisation is useful for enumerating possible distributive laws between two monad containers, which may help in developing no-go theorems for distributive laws between a larger class of monads.
By combining the work of Ahman and Uustalu on distributive laws for directed containers and our work, it is also easy enough to characterise mixed distributive laws.
